description: Those looking to complete the Cisco Certified Network Professional (CCNP) Routing and Switching certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the 300-101 Route exam for implementing Cisco IP routing, which is one of three exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The exam focuses on Cisco router implementation in medium and large environments and the exam objectives cover a wide range of topics including Layer 3 technologies, Infrastructure services and security, and others, which can also benefit those continuing to pursue the CCIE certification.
name: CCNP Routing and Switching - ROUTE
subtitle: Implementing Cisco IP Routing

episodes.description: The CCNP certification helps one when in the environment of working with hundreds of switches or routers and to achieve it, one will first need to have already achieved the CCENT and the CCNA certifications as a prerequisite. Viewers will hear an overview about the knowledge one needs to attain the CCNP certification, about the three exams one will need to take and the 300-101 Route exam objectives for implementing Cisco IP routing.
episodes.title: Overview of CCNP Route
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:08,175
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08,175 --> 00:00:09,388
The CCNP Routing and

3
00:00:09,388 --> 00:00:14,270
Switching certification is
the Cisco Certified Network Professional.

4
00:00:14,270 --> 00:00:17,790
It's the next step in most people's
careers after they achieve their CCNA,

5
00:00:17,790 --> 00:00:22,600
the Cisco Certified Network Associate,
and possibly some of the specializations.

6
00:00:22,600 --> 00:00:23,740
But the CCNP Routing and

7
00:00:23,740 --> 00:00:27,990
Switching really builds off of the,
well, CCNA Routing and Switching.

8
00:00:27,990 --> 00:00:33,290
And it basically takes our network
knowledge from just a handful of devices

9
00:00:33,290 --> 00:00:34,880
to something much larger.

10
00:00:34,880 --> 00:00:37,770
Right Ronnie, so in CCNA, how many
devices are we really talking about?

11
00:00:37,770 --> 00:00:41,320
>> We normally end up talking about
two routers, or maybe three routers,

12
00:00:41,320 --> 00:00:45,530
and a couple of switches, when we start
working with the devices themselves.

13
00:00:45,530 --> 00:00:48,270
Making sure first of all,
they can have basic connectivity, and

14
00:00:48,270 --> 00:00:50,700
that we can configure those devices.

15
00:00:50,700 --> 00:00:52,910
Once we start doing that,
we then connect them to routers.

16
00:00:52,910 --> 00:00:56,070
Again, multiple routers, making sure that
they can communicate with each other.

17
00:00:56,070 --> 00:01:00,340
But really building a small to medium
size network is what we normally hear

18
00:01:00,340 --> 00:01:02,010
the term being in CCNA.

19
00:01:02,010 --> 00:01:02,760
>> For a lot of people,

20
00:01:02,760 --> 00:01:07,040
the knowledge you gain from CCNA gets
you ready to set up branch offices.

21
00:01:07,040 --> 00:01:08,650
But what if you're not
working in a branch office?

22
00:01:08,650 --> 00:01:10,820
What if you're working in
the headquarters, the big node?

23
00:01:10,820 --> 00:01:13,290
You got hundreds of routers or
hundreds of switches.

24
00:01:13,290 --> 00:01:16,120
That's where CCNP Routing and
Switching comes in.

25
00:01:16,120 --> 00:01:21,229
And the exam that we're about to
prepare for is the 300-101 route exam.

26
00:01:21,229 --> 00:01:24,670
It's got a very simple name,
Implementing Cisco IP Routing.

27
00:01:24,670 --> 00:01:27,080
And what it is does is it
focuses solely on routers.

28
00:01:27,080 --> 00:01:31,260
That's different than the CCNA,
where we tackled them all kinda together.

29
00:01:31,260 --> 00:01:35,880
Under CCNP, we do routing,
switching, and troubleshooting.

30
00:01:35,880 --> 00:01:37,250
It's three separate exams,

31
00:01:37,250 --> 00:01:40,940
three separate areas, and
that let's us really drill down.

32
00:01:40,940 --> 00:01:44,592
We take all the same concepts that
you've already learned about in CCNA, or

33
00:01:44,592 --> 00:01:45,684
that you should have.

34
00:01:45,684 --> 00:01:48,190
You can't get your CCNP
without a CCNA first.

35
00:01:48,190 --> 00:01:51,934
We take those same concepts, and then we
go much deeper, and look at the advanced

36
00:01:51,934 --> 00:01:55,570
considerations we have when we
have large amounts of equipment.

37
00:01:55,570 --> 00:01:58,840
This gets you ready for the enterprise and
home office type model.

38
00:01:58,840 --> 00:02:00,590
I shouldn't say home office.

39
00:02:00,590 --> 00:02:01,670
That makes me think of my home.

40
00:02:01,670 --> 00:02:03,070
I mean like, headquarters.

41
00:02:04,320 --> 00:02:06,570
Let's talk a little bit about this exam.

42
00:02:06,570 --> 00:02:09,450
If you go to Cisco's website,
I've got it pulled up here.

43
00:02:09,450 --> 00:02:13,210
This is their CCNP Routing and
Switching page, and

44
00:02:13,210 --> 00:02:17,757
the way I get here is I just
type www.cisco.com/go/CCNP,

45
00:02:17,757 --> 00:02:22,830
/go is their little alias folder and
/CCNP sends you in here.

46
00:02:22,830 --> 00:02:26,133
They just kind of show that you
should already have your CCNA.

47
00:02:26,133 --> 00:02:29,021
You've got to have that to
progress to CCNP, and then for

48
00:02:29,021 --> 00:02:32,220
most people the next step is CCIE,
the high level.

49
00:02:32,220 --> 00:02:36,370
But in the CCNP, you've got three exams,
route, switch and t-shoot.

50
00:02:36,370 --> 00:02:38,120
And we're about to cover route.

51
00:02:39,140 --> 00:02:44,030
So nice to be able to break that down and
look at just the routing piece.

52
00:02:44,030 --> 00:02:48,150
The exam itself is very similar to
the other Cisco exams you may have taken.

53
00:02:48,150 --> 00:02:48,790
It's 120 minutes.

54
00:02:48,790 --> 00:02:55,820
You get two hours, which is not a ton of
time, and then you get 45 to 65 questions.

55
00:02:55,820 --> 00:02:58,860
That's a huge gap right there,
20 question gap.

56
00:02:58,860 --> 00:03:02,970
That means your exam could be up
to a third shorter than somebody

57
00:03:02,970 --> 00:03:06,230
sitting next to you,
in terms of the number of questions.

58
00:03:06,230 --> 00:03:09,260
But they're all two hours,
because of the labs.

59
00:03:09,260 --> 00:03:12,680
Some of the interactive labs in the exam
are more challenging than others, and

60
00:03:12,680 --> 00:03:13,930
they take more time.

61
00:03:13,930 --> 00:03:16,770
You may have more lab
questions than your neighbor.

62
00:03:16,770 --> 00:03:19,720
Your neighbor might have less than you,
or more multiple choice questions, so

63
00:03:19,720 --> 00:03:21,400
they kind of balance out.

64
00:03:21,400 --> 00:03:24,290
That's why there's such a variation
in the number of exams.

65
00:03:26,100 --> 00:03:27,730
Exams are all proctored
through Pearson VUE.

66
00:03:27,730 --> 00:03:29,158
If you wanna sign up for the exam,

67
00:03:29,158 --> 00:03:31,760
you've got to go to
the Pearson VUE website and do it.

68
00:03:31,760 --> 00:03:34,160
Cisco tests exclusively with Pearson VUE.

69
00:03:34,160 --> 00:03:36,300
You can't do it with
like Sylvan Prometric or

70
00:03:36,300 --> 00:03:39,660
the other testing vendors,
you've got to go to Pearson VUE.

71
00:03:39,660 --> 00:03:42,390
Fortunately, there's Pearson VUE
centers all over the world.

72
00:03:42,390 --> 00:03:44,794
It's not like you've got to
go to Cisco headquarters, or

73
00:03:44,794 --> 00:03:47,455
a Cisco authorized training provider,
or anything like that.

74
00:03:47,455 --> 00:03:50,140
You can just go to your nearest
VUE center and take the exam.

75
00:03:51,820 --> 00:03:54,920
Now, the exam itself,
be aware of a couple of things.

76
00:03:54,920 --> 00:03:56,240
First off, this is the 300-101.

77
00:03:56,240 --> 00:04:00,520
When you’re out there getting ready for
it, you’ll come across another number and,

78
00:04:00,520 --> 00:04:01,820
in fact, did they list it back here?

79
00:04:01,820 --> 00:04:04,140
I don’t think they did.

80
00:04:04,140 --> 00:04:05,905
Let me go to that, oops.

81
00:04:05,905 --> 00:04:07,630
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don’t wanna go back too far.

82
00:04:07,630 --> 00:04:12,720
What you’ll see is that the CCNP was
recently updated to version 2.0.

83
00:04:12,720 --> 00:04:18,200
It was version 1.1 before that, and really
1.0 to 1.1, they didn't change the exams.

84
00:04:18,200 --> 00:04:22,930
It had the same exam for a long time,
for seems like four years.

85
00:04:22,930 --> 00:04:24,510
It was a long time.

86
00:04:24,510 --> 00:04:28,780
And that means that there are a ton of
books and training materials that are out

87
00:04:28,780 --> 00:04:32,800
there, that are built upon the 1.0 and
1.1 curriculum, and not the 2.0.

88
00:04:32,800 --> 00:04:35,730
Well, depending on when
you're watching this series,

89
00:04:35,730 --> 00:04:39,900
if you're watching this live right now,
the 1.1 exam is still active.

90
00:04:39,900 --> 00:04:43,680
When you go to sign up for it,
you can actually still sign up for

91
00:04:43,680 --> 00:04:45,730
the older exams.

92
00:04:45,730 --> 00:04:50,090
Let me do a search for
the CCNP route class.

93
00:04:50,090 --> 00:04:52,000
The class that they do.

94
00:04:52,000 --> 00:04:54,370
And well that's Global Knowledge,
is not who I wanted.

95
00:04:54,370 --> 00:04:55,950
I want Cisco.
>> There we go.

96
00:04:55,950 --> 00:04:57,030
>> If we go to Cisco's.

97
00:04:57,030 --> 00:04:58,741
Oh, that just took me right
back to the same page.

98
00:04:58,741 --> 00:05:02,300
Oh, if I just scroll down,
see there we go.

99
00:05:02,300 --> 00:05:03,820
Notice here, for the required exams for

100
00:05:03,820 --> 00:05:07,770
the CCNP, you've got to do route,
switch, and tshoot.

101
00:05:07,770 --> 00:05:09,650
But see how there's two exams.

102
00:05:09,650 --> 00:05:15,544
642-902, that's the 1.0, 1.1 exam.

103
00:05:15,544 --> 00:05:19,363
Last data test is January 29th, 2015.

104
00:05:19,363 --> 00:05:22,970
We're filming this in October of 2014,
so that's three more months.

105
00:05:22,970 --> 00:05:24,680
You could still get in and do that.

106
00:05:24,680 --> 00:05:26,570
If you've got a bunch of materials
that are built off of the old

107
00:05:26,570 --> 00:05:28,370
content, that's fine.

108
00:05:28,370 --> 00:05:31,290
And if you watch our new content,
you'll actually get you ready for

109
00:05:31,290 --> 00:05:32,590
the old exam too, just as well,

110
00:05:32,590 --> 00:05:35,990
we just cover some additional things
that aren't on that exam yet.

111
00:05:35,990 --> 00:05:40,555
But, if you're moving forward,
you really need to do the new exam.

112
00:05:40,555 --> 00:05:45,140
They'll both give you the same CCNP,
they'll both expire in two years.

113
00:05:45,140 --> 00:05:48,460
You gotta do continuing education, so
you have to re-up every two years.

114
00:05:48,460 --> 00:05:50,780
Doesn't matter whether you did
the old exam or the new exam.

115
00:05:50,780 --> 00:05:52,430
Cisco doesn't get particular like that.

116
00:05:53,610 --> 00:05:56,370
But, if you're just starting out,
definitely do the new one,

117
00:05:56,370 --> 00:06:00,350
because after January 29, 2015,
you can't take the old one anymore.

118
00:06:00,350 --> 00:06:04,890
And so if you prepared for the older exam
and now you missed that date, you've gotta

119
00:06:04,890 --> 00:06:08,240
kind of start over and pick up all the
differences to get to the new end date.

120
00:06:08,240 --> 00:06:09,740
It'll make life harder
on you than it should.

121
00:06:11,180 --> 00:06:14,244
And you'll see all the exams
have been updated, switch and

122
00:06:14,244 --> 00:06:17,440
tshoot, which we're not
covering in this series.

123
00:06:17,440 --> 00:06:20,574
On the round side,
we're really focused on that 300-101.

124
00:06:20,574 --> 00:06:26,680
And the 300-101 objectives are focused
specifically on routing topics.

125
00:06:26,680 --> 00:06:29,710
And you'll see that it
starts out really low level.

126
00:06:29,710 --> 00:06:32,510
General concepts that you should
already be familiar with.

127
00:06:33,850 --> 00:06:37,250
The thing is, you should already be
a CCNA, but when did you get it?

128
00:06:37,250 --> 00:06:39,280
You could have got it years ago, you know?

129
00:06:39,280 --> 00:06:40,450
Maybe you don't use Cisco everyday.

130
00:06:40,450 --> 00:06:43,320
This information gets
kind of out of your head.

131
00:06:43,320 --> 00:06:44,910
We covered that in
the beginning as a refresher.

132
00:06:46,830 --> 00:06:48,010
After that we go into Layer 2.

133
00:06:48,010 --> 00:06:51,450
Now you might be saying to yourself, wait
a minute Don, didn't you just say this was

134
00:06:51,450 --> 00:06:55,160
a route show, a route exam, why would
we talk about Layer 2 technologies?

135
00:06:55,160 --> 00:06:58,390
Well, even though our
router operates at Layer 3,

136
00:06:58,390 --> 00:07:01,100
what's going on at Layer
2 makes a difference.

137
00:07:01,100 --> 00:07:04,020
And so you'll see inside of Layer 2
technologies where it starts to break

138
00:07:04,020 --> 00:07:08,250
down things like PPP and Chap,
which your router might need to

139
00:07:08,250 --> 00:07:12,880
participate in as part of a WAN link,
or frame relay, for example.

140
00:07:12,880 --> 00:07:16,050
You don't do frame relay to a switch,
which is a Layer 2 device.

141
00:07:16,050 --> 00:07:19,530
You do frame, well I guess, if you
had frame relay switch you would, but

142
00:07:19,530 --> 00:07:21,510
a normal Ethernet switch you wouldn't.

143
00:07:21,510 --> 00:07:24,300
But you do terminate
frame relay on a router.

144
00:07:24,300 --> 00:07:24,930
And so

145
00:07:24,930 --> 00:07:29,010
we need to understand how that works in
those Layer 2 sides of that technology.

146
00:07:30,200 --> 00:07:33,240
Now some of that, like frame relay,
used to be covered in-depth in CCNA.

147
00:07:33,240 --> 00:07:36,620
And they started to phase some of that
out of there and move it up to CCNP,

148
00:07:36,620 --> 00:07:39,604
because it's less likely that people
in a branch are gonna encounter that.

149
00:07:39,604 --> 00:07:41,780
They've all switched to cable,
DSL or whatever.

150
00:07:44,370 --> 00:07:46,110
We've got Layer 3 technologies
what comes up next.

151
00:07:46,110 --> 00:07:49,566
And on the Layer 3 notice
these exam percentages.

152
00:07:49,566 --> 00:07:50,834
>> [LAUGH]
>> 10%, 10%,

153
00:07:50,834 --> 00:07:53,750
40% of the exam comes
from this one section.

154
00:07:53,750 --> 00:07:56,155
Almost half the exam is right from here.

155
00:07:56,155 --> 00:07:57,083
It's routing right?

156
00:07:57,083 --> 00:07:58,511
Layer 3.

157
00:07:58,511 --> 00:08:02,995
And if you look at what's inside of there,
it's stuff that well, that you'd expect.

158
00:08:02,995 --> 00:08:06,935
We can see things like understanding
IP addressing, VOSM, ARP,

159
00:08:06,935 --> 00:08:08,765
DHCP all that good stuff.

160
00:08:08,765 --> 00:08:10,345
We've got IPv6 addressing.

161
00:08:10,345 --> 00:08:14,105
Notice the exam pretty much
treats them equally now.

162
00:08:14,105 --> 00:08:17,190
You used to get just a little
bit of IPv6 on the exam.

163
00:08:17,190 --> 00:08:18,510
Now you get a lot of it.

164
00:08:18,510 --> 00:08:19,990
That's the way that we're moving forward.

165
00:08:19,990 --> 00:08:21,740
You need to understand it.

166
00:08:21,740 --> 00:08:23,550
After that we've got
our routing protocols.

167
00:08:23,550 --> 00:08:27,370
We've got static routing,
default routing, our different types,

168
00:08:27,370 --> 00:08:31,850
and then we jump into EIGRP in OSPF and
BGP.

169
00:08:33,280 --> 00:08:36,910
Now EIGRP in OSPF,
you've already learned about in the CCNA.

170
00:08:36,910 --> 00:08:40,320
We go further and show some of
the more advanced configurations.

171
00:08:40,320 --> 00:08:42,350
BGP-
>> I haven't seen.

172
00:08:42,350 --> 00:08:44,655
>> Actually,
do they cover that in the newest?

173
00:08:44,655 --> 00:08:45,380
>> No.
>> No, still no.

174
00:08:45,380 --> 00:08:48,470
I knew they were flashing out the CCNA so
you never know.

175
00:08:48,470 --> 00:08:49,820
But yeah, for

176
00:08:49,820 --> 00:08:53,300
BGP, for a lot of you, this might be
the first time you're exposed to it.

177
00:08:53,300 --> 00:08:56,170
And the Border Gateway Protocol,
boy that thing is important, so

178
00:08:56,170 --> 00:08:58,540
we'll get a chance to see that and
start to work with it.

179
00:08:58,540 --> 00:09:02,840
There's also some really cool
stuff that I enjoy like VRF.

180
00:09:02,840 --> 00:09:07,120
Taking one physical router and
dividing it into multiple virtual routers.

181
00:09:07,120 --> 00:09:10,400
That used to be ISP level stuff,
but now we can do it

182
00:09:10,400 --> 00:09:14,790
here inside a CCNP at the regular
enterprise level and it's the neat stuff!

183
00:09:14,790 --> 00:09:17,860
You can do some really cool things
with VRF, but if you're doing MPLS,

184
00:09:17,860 --> 00:09:20,380
that's where VRF really comes in handy.

185
00:09:20,380 --> 00:09:24,754
But you'll see all the different route
topics, and just look at that exam and

186
00:09:24,754 --> 00:09:28,340
be like, if it's huge, with all
the different things that get covered.

187
00:09:28,340 --> 00:09:30,970
And really valuable stuff, so
that will be a huge section for this show.

188
00:09:33,620 --> 00:09:35,370
After that, we've got VPN technologies.

189
00:09:35,370 --> 00:09:39,450
Now Cisco really wants you
to terminate VPNs on an ASA.

190
00:09:39,450 --> 00:09:41,410
On their firewall appliances.

191
00:09:41,410 --> 00:09:43,150
But your routers can build a VPN.

192
00:09:43,150 --> 00:09:47,340
And so we'll take a look at things
like dynamic VPNs, the easy VPN, or

193
00:09:47,340 --> 00:09:52,030
easy virtual networking is what it's
called now, GRE tunnels, we'll get

194
00:09:52,030 --> 00:09:55,310
a chance to see those, how they work,
and how we can use them on our routers.

195
00:09:55,310 --> 00:09:57,340
You may not use that in production, but

196
00:09:57,340 --> 00:09:59,240
it's important to understand
that the feature is there and

197
00:09:59,240 --> 00:10:02,990
understand how to use it, so that you know
whether or not it's the right fit for you.

198
00:10:05,270 --> 00:10:07,180
After that,
we've got Infrastructure Security,

199
00:10:07,180 --> 00:10:10,620
where we start to take a look
at securing our devices.

200
00:10:10,620 --> 00:10:14,680
If you did the CCNA Security,
you already got a preview of some of this.

201
00:10:14,680 --> 00:10:17,300
How to use RADIUS to
authenticate on your routers.

202
00:10:17,300 --> 00:10:20,020
How to secure your VTYs, and so on.

203
00:10:20,020 --> 00:10:24,060
But if you didn't do CCNA Security,
here's your first exposure to it.

204
00:10:24,060 --> 00:10:27,500
We need to understand how to properly
secure our routers to prevent attacks.

205
00:10:28,980 --> 00:10:31,080
And then lastly, Infrastructure Services.

206
00:10:31,080 --> 00:10:34,980
This is what I call the leftovers right.

207
00:10:34,980 --> 00:10:38,720
All the other cool junk you can do on
your router that they didn't include

208
00:10:38,720 --> 00:10:41,210
in the other modules cuz
they just didn't quite fit.

209
00:10:41,210 --> 00:10:42,190
And so, they throw it in here.

210
00:10:42,190 --> 00:10:43,630
And that doesn't mean
this stuff is worthless.

211
00:10:43,630 --> 00:10:44,220
It's good stuff.

212
00:10:44,220 --> 00:10:45,790
This is my favorite section.

213
00:10:45,790 --> 00:10:49,970
Cuz you start getting into things
like using SCP to securely copy data,

214
00:10:49,970 --> 00:10:54,190
and how to configure SNMP logging,
network time protocol,

215
00:10:54,190 --> 00:10:56,370
all this other really good stuff.

216
00:10:56,370 --> 00:11:00,060
IPSLAs, netflow, really fun stuff.

217
00:11:00,060 --> 00:11:01,940
You guys, you'll really enjoy
that section at the end,

218
00:11:01,940 --> 00:11:04,760
because it's just cool technology
after cool technology.

219
00:11:04,760 --> 00:11:06,740
That's kind of how we wrap it up.

220
00:11:06,740 --> 00:11:10,300
But you'll see that all of this
is being implemented on routers.

221
00:11:10,300 --> 00:11:13,110
At no point did we see a switch,
not even Layer 3 switching.

222
00:11:13,110 --> 00:11:15,720
We really don't even deal with
Layer 3 switching in this one,

223
00:11:15,720 --> 00:11:21,680
it's really just routing on routers.

224
00:11:21,680 --> 00:11:25,970
For most people, this will be the first
exam you take on the way to your CCNP.

225
00:11:25,970 --> 00:11:27,540
It doesn't have to be.

226
00:11:27,540 --> 00:11:30,350
Cisco doesn't mandate that you
take these exams in order.

227
00:11:30,350 --> 00:11:32,530
I know some people like
to start out on switch,

228
00:11:32,530 --> 00:11:34,690
because they feel it's
a little bit easier.

229
00:11:34,690 --> 00:11:37,340
I think most people get more hands on
experience with a switch than they do on

230
00:11:37,340 --> 00:11:40,420
a router,
because you change switches all the time.

231
00:11:40,420 --> 00:11:42,100
It doesn't really matter
which one you start with,

232
00:11:42,100 --> 00:11:43,760
you're welcome to start
with the other one.

233
00:11:43,760 --> 00:11:46,790
But TSHOOT really does
need to be the last one.

234
00:11:46,790 --> 00:11:50,830
And that's because TSHOOT
draws from switch and route.

235
00:11:50,830 --> 00:11:55,600
And it says, okay, you learned how things
were gonna go when they work right.

236
00:11:55,600 --> 00:11:56,590
What happens when they work wrong?

237
00:11:56,590 --> 00:12:00,150
And they mix it together, and so,
you really need the switch and

238
00:12:00,150 --> 00:12:03,320
route knowledge before you take TSHOOT.

239
00:12:03,320 --> 00:12:07,340
Just keep that in mind when you plan the
order for taking these exams and studying.

240
00:12:07,340 --> 00:12:10,770
>> When you're studying remember,
the fundamental concepts you learned about

241
00:12:10,770 --> 00:12:13,450
in your CCNA studies
are really gonna help.

242
00:12:13,450 --> 00:12:14,400
Don't just overlook it.

243
00:12:14,400 --> 00:12:16,660
If you go, hey, I really wanted CCNP, but

244
00:12:16,660 --> 00:12:20,600
you just didn't want to spend time in
the CCNA studies, you've gotta go back.

245
00:12:20,600 --> 00:12:23,600
Fundamentals for
this exam are gonna be so important.

246
00:12:23,600 --> 00:12:27,170
You're not gonna realize it until you're
just partway through and you're gonna say,

247
00:12:27,170 --> 00:12:28,840
hey, I remember doing some of this.

248
00:12:28,840 --> 00:12:30,780
But it's gonna be really important
when we get into the route,

249
00:12:30,780 --> 00:12:33,610
into the deeper stuff,
for the routing protocols,

250
00:12:33,610 --> 00:12:36,890
about how important it is that we
know just the basic operations.

251
00:12:36,890 --> 00:12:38,240
And so the more that you review that,

252
00:12:38,240 --> 00:12:41,680
the more prepared you're gonna also
be as you head into this topic.

253
00:12:41,680 --> 00:12:42,940
>> Yeah, absolutely yeah.

254
00:12:42,940 --> 00:12:44,450
And you know this is a pretty fun one.

255
00:12:44,450 --> 00:12:47,630
I know for me, when I was learning Cisco,
and studying for

256
00:12:47,630 --> 00:12:52,580
a lot of this stuff, the CCNL, that was
great but I kind of, by that point,

257
00:12:52,580 --> 00:12:56,040
I already knew how to take a router
out of the box and get it turned on.

258
00:12:56,040 --> 00:13:00,410
I didn't learn anything shocking and
new when I was studying for CCNL.

259
00:13:00,410 --> 00:13:03,210
This was in 2000, so 14 years ago.

260
00:13:03,210 --> 00:13:08,400
But when I started studying for the CCNP,
that was when I learned really cool stuff.

261
00:13:08,400 --> 00:13:09,370
And I learned stuff where I was,

262
00:13:09,370 --> 00:13:11,640
man I can't wait until I
get to the office tomorrow.

263
00:13:11,640 --> 00:13:12,600
Because I'm going to implement this.

264
00:13:12,600 --> 00:13:13,662
Which is a terrible idea, right?

265
00:13:13,662 --> 00:13:15,981
>> [LAUGH]
>> You don't want to rush right out and

266
00:13:15,981 --> 00:13:17,070
implement something.

267
00:13:17,070 --> 00:13:20,080
Don, 14 years ago was a little more-
>> Bearing.

268
00:13:20,080 --> 00:13:20,790
>> Yeah.

269
00:13:20,790 --> 00:13:22,055
Risk taking, I suppose.

270
00:13:22,055 --> 00:13:24,790
>> [LAUGH]
>> But you will learn cool stuff,

271
00:13:24,790 --> 00:13:28,690
and you'll find that your routers are way
more powerful than you thought they were.

272
00:13:28,690 --> 00:13:30,120
And that they can do
some really neat things,

273
00:13:30,120 --> 00:13:31,040
if you just know how to turn it on.

274
00:13:31,040 --> 00:13:32,710
>> Right.
>> And that's what we're gonna see

275
00:13:32,710 --> 00:13:33,950
here in this show.

276
00:13:33,950 --> 00:13:35,170
>> Right.

277
00:13:35,170 --> 00:13:37,410
>> If that sounds like something
you guys want to learn about,

278
00:13:37,410 --> 00:13:39,080
you're in the right place.

279
00:13:39,080 --> 00:13:40,590
If you're just getting started with Cisco,

280
00:13:40,590 --> 00:13:45,450
I do recommend you jump over to our
CCNA show first, or CCENT and CCNA.

281
00:13:45,450 --> 00:13:48,794
Make sure you get the basics under your
under your belt, and then after that,

282
00:13:48,794 --> 00:13:50,657
come back and
see us right here with route.

283
00:13:50,657 --> 00:13:54,836
But if you've already got that knowledge
and you're excited, pumped up, well,

284
00:13:54,836 --> 00:13:55,445
we are too.

285
00:13:55,445 --> 00:13:56,375
We're ready to get into this.

286
00:13:56,375 --> 00:13:59,815
Ronnie and I both,
we're old time Cisco guys, and

287
00:13:59,815 --> 00:14:02,055
really enjoy working with equipment,
it's a lot of fun.

288
00:14:02,055 --> 00:14:03,255
>> Yeah, it is.

289
00:14:03,255 --> 00:14:05,865
>> All right, well,
hope to see you guys in the show.

290
00:14:05,865 --> 00:14:06,365
Take it easy.

episodes.description: Cisco Express Forwarding (CEF) is a feature found inside Cisco routers which is a special way of handling data that moving through routers that can route packets at near wire speed. Viewers will hear about some basic networking principles and hear discussions on the Forwarding Information Base (FIB) and Adjacency Table used by Cisco Express Forwarding.
episodes.title: Cisco Express Forwarding

episodes.description: In a small network environment, things work pretty easily, but in a large network, a few more problems start to arise and a possible solution could be to run a dynamic routing protocol. Viewers will hear about networking challenges including some of the challenges when sending data through multiple routers with redundant paths, some of the basic concepts of data moving through the network, as well as see demonstrations of the routing process as data moves through multiple routers.
episodes.title: General Network Challenges

episodes.description: When it comes to IP operations, it behaves one way for local communication and a different way for remote communications. Viewers will hear about IP operations, basic router functions when packets are too large or bounce around multiple routers and the process of breaking large data into segments for data delivery.
episodes.title: IP Operations Part 1

episodes.description: ICMP is a protocol that is used to receive status messages back from devices to see if connections are valid and networks are working. Viewers will hear about ICMP unreachables and redirects, IPv6 and IPv4 fragmentation and time-to-live (TTL).
episodes.title: IP Operations Part 2

episodes.description: TCP is a very frequently used protocol that provides reliable delivery of communications across the network. Viewers will hear the difference between TCP and UDP traffic, the use of windowing for TCP traffic, as well as discussions on the MTU, MSS, Latency and other TCP operations.
episodes.title: TCP Operations

episodes.description: UDP is designed for fast communications, but it does not provide reliable delivery of communication data. Viewers will hear about UDP operations and some of the major challenge that it can cause with TCP traffic called TCP starvation.
episodes.title: UDP Operations

episodes.description: Even little changes to the configurable values inside a dynamic routing protocol can cause problems throughout the rest of the infrastructure. Viewers will hear about changes with the network including routing parameters of Administrative Distance and Metrics, migration to IPv6 addressing, using dual stacking technology and will also hear about the two different routing protocol migration strategies: changing AD and a moving wave change using Route Redistribution.
episodes.title: Proposed Changes

episodes.description: Layer 2 technologies make up a relatively small portion of the Route exam, but are still important to understand. Viewers will hear discussions on the sub-objectives that will be covered including configuring PPP and explaining Frame Relay.
episodes.title: Layer 2 Technologies

episodes.description: Point to Point Protocol (PPP) is designed to work in serial based networks, which uses analog communications compared to most communications used today which are digital. Viewers will hear how to implement authentication to PPP and see the basic Layer 2 configuration of both PPP and PPPoE on routers.
episodes.title: Configure PPP

episodes.description: Frame Relay is an older technology for connecting across a Service Provider's Network, which can be really easy to implement. Viewers will see the basic configuration of frame relay in a Point-to-Point configuration, Multipoint Configuration and Full Mesh using physical interfaces (point-to-point) and sub interfaces (multipoint and full-mesh) to show Frame relay’s versatility and use basic commands to verify configuration.
episodes.title: Frame Relay

episodes.description: For the Route exam one will need to be able to identify, configure and verify IPv4 addressing and subnetting, which contains three different types of addressing: unicast, broadcast and multicast communications. Viewers will hear about some of the basic IPv4 addressing concepts, the difference between the different types of IPv4 addressing and how to assign IPv4 addressing using DHCP and DHCP relay, as well as hear about how ARP functions within a network and across a network.
episodes.title: IP Addressing

episodes.description: IPv6 is only recently seeing adoption because of the lack of IPv4 addresses and added features to IPv6, but the majority of environments still work with IPv4 because a lot of money has been invested into it and many ISPs don't even support IPv6 yet. Viewers will hear about IPv6 on Cisco routers including the various types of addressing available, when each type of address is typically used, automatic configuration and DHCP for IPv6.
episodes.title: IPv6 Addressing

episodes.description: Static routing is when one gives a command to a router to manually go somewhere, which overrides any other route preference. Viewers will hear about configuring static routing including the pros and cons of using static routing and hear demonstrations on how to configure it and use IP SLA to "track" the viability of the next hop.
episodes.title: Static Routing

episodes.description: A default route takes the packets that come into a router that don't match any entry on the routing table and forwards it to a particular interface or IP address. Viewers will hear about the use of default routing on Cisco routers, how to configure static default routes and how to redistribute a default route into OSPF and EIGRP.
episodes.title: Default Routing

episodes.description: Cisco wants to ensure those pursuing the CCNP certification know the difference between different dynamic routing protocols. Viewers will hear about the general types of dynamic routing protocols, which include: distance vector, link-state and path vector.
episodes.title: Routing Protocols

episodes.description: Administrative distance is something Cisco routers keeps track for different routes that might be considered the best possible route based on the protocol used. Viewers will hear about the use of Administrative Distance on Cisco routers and about changing the default administrative distances to give preference of one routing protocol over another even when the metrics are different.
episodes.title: Administrative Distance

episodes.description: Passive interfaces are a tool built into Cisco routers, which allows one to have a little more control over where a routing protocol runs. By default routing protocols advertise out of all interfaces configured in the routing protocol and passive interfaces can be used to prevent advertising specific protocols. Viewers will hear discussions about passive interfaces and the various behaviors when using EIGRP, OSPF and RIP.
episodes.title: Passive Interfaces

episodes.description: VPN Routing and Forwarding (VRF-lite) works by partitioning a routing table and is used at the ISP level to help separate traffic between customers using the same equipment. Viewers will hear about the functions of VRF-lite and see demonstrations on how to configure it.
episodes.title: VRF Lite

episodes.description: Eventually one's network grows to the point where one's needs are complex enough that just learning the routes isn't enough, but will need to manipulate routes on the routing table to filter out certain routes. Viewers will hear about methods used to filter routes while using any protocol and see and demonstrations of the use of prefix lists and distribute lists on routers using EIGRP, OSPF and BGP.
episodes.title: Route Filtering

episodes.description: Route redistribution is the exchanging of a route from one routing protocol to another. Viewers will hear about the use of route redistribution and about configuring and verifying redistribution between routing protocols.
episodes.title: Route Redistribution

episodes.description: Route summarization is when smaller routes are combined into one larger route to reduce the size of the routing table. Viewers will hear discussions on the importance of keeping a routing table as concise as possible, the basic theory of route summarization, the use of auto summarization and the importance of manual summarization of routes, as well as hear about configuring routers for manual summarization.
episodes.title: Route Summarization

episodes.description: Normal routing will only do destination routing, but policy based routing uses customized policies to take certain actions based on if traffic meets a specified criteria. Viewers will hear about policy based routing and the types of things it can be influenced by like source addresses, inbound interfaces, and protocols.
episodes.title: Policy Based Routing

episodes.description: Route maps are a powerful tool inside a Cisco router, which can be used for a lot of things including filtering BGP traffic and allows one to affect certain routes without influencing others. Viewers will hear about one of the most powerful ways to control and influence routing through the use of route maps.
episodes.title: Route Maps

episodes.description: Routing loops are something that’s really important to be aware of, which EIGRP and RIP are especially susceptible to, so it is important that one implements loop prevention techniques to protect one’s network from those problems. Viewers will hear about implementing loop prevention techniques and the three technologies behind it: split horizon, poison reverse and route tags.
episodes.title: Loop Prevention

episodes.description: RIPv2 is a classless routing protocol, which can be easily configured and deployed. Viewers will hear about some of the fundamental concepts and configuration of using RIPv2, how to verify its functionality, how to better manage rip by using passive-interfaces and how to configure rip to distribute a default route.
episodes.title: Configure and Verify RIPv2

episodes.description: RIPng is a newer version of RIP that works with IPv6. Viewers will hear about configuring RIPng on routers and some of its similarities and differences with RIPv2.
episodes.title: Describe RIPng

episodes.description: There's about ten different packet types that get sent back and forth between EIGRP routers under certain conditions and it’s good to have an understanding all of the communication happening in the background and the different packet types for troubleshooting purposes. Viewers will hear about the main packet types that EIGRP routers use to establish neighboring adjacencies and to keep the routes up to date between them.
episodes.title: EIGRP Packet Types

episodes.description: Anytime one can see more neighbors, the better accurate representation of one’s network they are going to have. Viewers will hear about setting up EIGRP neighbor relationships and simply getting EIGRP to work, as well as how to get past some of the issues when working with frame relay or MPLS using the neighbor command.
episodes.title: EIGRP Neighbors

episodes.description: It's a good idea to configure authentication between EIGRP routers to verify that the EIGRP neighbors are who they say they are and prevent the possibility of internal attacks. Viewers will hear about configuring basic authentication and even authentication by using multiple keys.
episodes.title: EIGRP Neighbors Part 2

episodes.description: Properly using EIGRP stubs can help to optimize performance on a network. Viewers will hear about configuring EIGRP stubs and the types of stubs one can set up to make things more efficient.
episodes.title: Configure EIGRP Stubs

episodes.description: If a routing protocol finds more than one way to get to the same destination then load balancing could be an option, where computing resources are balanced between multiple paths to get to the same destination. Viewers will hear about load balancing especially with EIGRP, key metrics EIGRP looks at by default, and making sure it does equal cost load balancing.
episodes.title: EIGRP Load Balancing

episodes.description: When EIGRP makes a decision, it by default looks at two things, which are bandwidth and delay. Viewers will hear about the way EIGRP makes routing decisions based on the composite metric calculated by DUAL-FSM, the five metrics that EIGRP uses, and how to manipulate the K values to get different results.
episodes.title: EIGRP Metrics

episodes.description: EIGRP for IPv6 is a configuration that shouldn't be ignored when preparing for the ROUTE exam. When Cisco created EIGRP they didn’t create it to handle only a single protocol, but created it as a framework capable of routing any protocol. Viewers will hear how to configure EIGRP running on top of IPv6 and also how it compares to what is normally seen with EIGRP.
episodes.title: EIGRP for IPv6

episodes.description: Packets are what are exchanged for OSPF adjacencies to be established in OSPF networks and understanding the different OSPF packet types is useful to know for understanding how OSPF works and also for the purposes of troubleshooting. Viewers will hear about the five primary OSPF packet types and see demonstrations on how to see the packets during the neighboring process.
episodes.title: OSPF Packet Types

episodes.description: When two routers decide to exchange routes, neighbor relationships get built up. Viewers will hear about the forming of adjacencies and the eight OSPF neighbor states as the process happens, as well as how debugging the states can help in troubleshooting OSPF.
episodes.title: OSPF Neighbors

episodes.description: By default OSPF doesn't do any authentication, which one should try to implement especially if one is on a multi-access network to prevent building up OSPF adjacencies with rogue routers. Viewers will hear about using the authentication mechanism between neighboring OSPF routers, the two possible modes of OSPF authentication, and also see demonstrations of how to configure authentication on the interface.
episodes.title: OSPF Neighbors Part 2

episodes.description: Areas are a special way to sub-divide an OSPF autonomous system and improve its performance, but inside an area, not every network is treated equally, so it's important to understand network types and see how they respond differently. Viewers will hear about the five different network types inside of OSPF and the situations in which each of them are used.
episodes.title: OSPF Network Types

episodes.description: In OSPF, Link State Advertisements (LSAs) are the way in which routers exchange information between each other. Viewers will hear about routing information that is exchanged in OSPF and the 11 different types of LSAs one might see inside of OSPF.
episodes.title: OSPF LSA Types

episodes.description: There are four route types found in OSPF, but in a standard deployment one really just sees one regular OSPF route. Viewers will hear about the results of the LSA exchanges that occur between OSPF routers, the four different route types found in OSPF and how one can identify them and actually see how they are working.
episodes.title: OSPF Route Types

episodes.description: At the point where one's network gets bigger and has more traffic and communication on it, one will need to start dividing up their network into areas. Having deployment set up for just one area is easier from an administrative standpoint, but Cisco recommends splitting up into multiple areas when one’s network gets up to 50 routers. Viewers will hear about connecting to a multi and standard area OSPF and hear about the backbone area that acts as a transit network.
episodes.title: OSPF Area Types

episodes.description: When one wants to start shrinking their routing table down, the best way to do that is by configuring an area called a stub, which is considered a dead end in OSPF. Viewers will hear discussions about the different area types, the areas used to optimize a multi-area OSPF network, as well as see the configuration and results of implementing different area types.
episodes.title: OSPF Area Types Part 2

episodes.description: Virtual links are a temporary solution used to get past network failure, which go against the rules of OSPF and work to get the user at least some connectivity. Viewers will hear about how virtual links work and the key to getting it configured.
episodes.title: OSPF Virtual Links

episodes.description: OSPF path preference looks for the best line when multiple ways to get to a destination exist and chooses the one with the lowest cost. Viewers will hear about the way that OSPF chooses a path among multiple paths to a destination and hear about the ability to manipulate routes and the cost so that one can be preferred over another.
episodes.title: OSPF Path Preference

episodes.description: OSPF version 3 was made to support IPv6, unlike version 2 which was made only to support IPv4. Since they are built for different protocols they are completely incompatible, but their configuration is nearly identical. Viewers will hear about configuring IPv6 for OSPFv3 and also how to verify that it is operational.
episodes.title: OSPF for IPv6

episodes.description: The Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is an exterior protocol, which was intended and configured to route the internet, and not necessarily an enterprise or home environment, which tries to provide a loop-free topology on a global level. Viewers will hear about why one would choose to use BGP and the basic BGP characteristics, theory and terminology necessary for understanding how it works.
episodes.title: Border Gateway Protocol

episodes.description: Interior and exterior BGP have different functions, whereas IGPs are designed for companies and enterprises to handle dynamic routing on a network and have control over things like routers and route manipulation, external BGP relies on other routers to get to a destination, but it can't control them. Viewers will see how to setup a connection to a BGP network, basic BGP configurations, the differences in configuring internal BGP as opposed to external BGP and hear about some of the things one needs to be aware of when it comes to BGP and verifying if it is operating.
episodes.title: Border Gateway Protocol Part 2

episodes.description: For BGP there is a lot of configuration to do, which security isn't a great concern in BGP, but one should employ at least a little bit of security. Viewers will hear about some more advanced features one can configure like security and authentication and see demonstrations on how to configure authentication between BGP peers and how to use BGP Peer Groups to quickly configure large quantities of BGP peers with similar configurations.
episodes.title: Border Gateway Protocol Part 3

episodes.description: BGP was written to route the internet, which as a whole is expansive and with IPv4 networks is also expansive, but BGP is also flexible enough to work with other protocols like IPv6. Viewers will hear discussions on how BGP Address Families can be used to allow BGP to route for protocols beyond the default of IPv4 and see demonstrations for various "show" commands that can be used to monitor and troubleshoot BGP.
episodes.title: Border Gateway Protocol Part 4

episodes.description: BGP is a path vector protocol, which looks for the fewest number of autonomous systems it can pass through and uses several attributes to determine which route is preferred. Viewers will hear how BGP makes decisions, the different things that can influence the path BGP chooses and attributes that are a part of the BGP standard.
episodes.title: BGP Attributes

episodes.description: BGP doesn't see a lot of the underlying infrastructure unlike EIGRP and OSPF, which have a really good view of the network, so one often might have a better understanding of the network to influence a route preference than the protocol itself. Viewers will see demonstrations of manipulating attributes to have some control over what route BGP picks and have influence over BGP performance, traffic coming into and out of an autonomous system.
episodes.title: BGP Attributes Part 2

episodes.description: VPN technology can actually be useful for routing protocols in the case of building VPN tunnels between one router to another to create connectivity and reestablish a connection even over an untrusted network to avoid problems brought on by network failure or mask other complexities on the network. Viewers will hear about three different VPN tunnels one needs to be aware of, some of the uses of Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) on Cisco IOS routers and see demonstrations of how to configure a tunnel between two Cisco IOS routers.
episodes.title: VPN Technologies

episodes.description: Using a GRE tunnel over a private network is okay to do, but not the best idea if being sent through an ISP because of the lack of encryption. Viewers will hear about how IPSec, DM-VPNs and EasyVPN can be used to create encrypted tunnels between Cisco IOS routers and see a demonstration of applying IPSec to a GRE tunnel to create a secure connection between two routers.
episodes.title: VPN Technologies Part 2

episodes.description: Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting (AAA) are all facets that can be utilized in RADIUS and TACACS+ servers and can be used to improve login security on a Cisco IOS router, where RADIUS is great with accounting and authentication and TACACS+ is good with authentication and authorization. When it comes to the particular server utilization, one is usually running Cisco ACS, which runs both RADIUS and TACACS+. Viewers will see demonstrations on how to configure the IOS to use RADIUS, TACACS+ servers to authenticate users and see how to use AAA groups to provide redundancy for the login process.
episodes.title: AAA

episodes.description: A router is typically a border device, which makes it a target for attacks and for hackers to take control of, but one can utilize device access control and implement security tactics to secure a router and regulate who has access to the computing resources. Viewers will hear about some of the basic security best practices to protect a router, the AutoSecure script to help harden an IOS router, and see different settings and what each service does to increase/decrease the router's overall attack surface.
episodes.title: Device Access Control

episodes.description: Understanding how the different security features inside a router function, can help to properly and effectively implement them to protect a system. Viewers will hear about some of the security features inside a router including different access control lists that filter traffic passing through a router, reverse path verification and also Unicast Reverse Path Forwarding (URPF).
episodes.title: Router Security Features

episodes.description: The device management objective of the CCNP exam includes a long list of services that run on a Cisco router that one should be aware of as a network professional. Viewers will hear information on various small services available to manage Cisco equipment, which covers configuring and securing a Console, Telnet, SSH, and web access (HTTP and HTTPS) as well as some of the lesser known features for each.
episodes.title: Device Management

episodes.description: One thing one will have to handle sooner or later with a Cisco router is getting files like iOS or configuration files copied to or from the router and being able to transmit data back and forth. Viewers will hear about ways to securely move files back and forth between systems, using a Cisco router as an FTP, TFTP and SCP client to upload and download files from the IOS CLI and see demonstrations on how to configure a Cisco router as a TFTP or SCP server to allow users to upload and download files to a router from their own workstations.
episodes.title: Device Management Part 2

episodes.description: Management protocols run in the background on a router and can be useful for monitoring the routers functionality and provide information about it. Viewers will hear about some of the management protocols available for monitoring routers and see demonstrations of configuring the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) on a Cisco router to allow monitoring health and utilization information in the Cisco IOS and configuring Cisco IOS to transmit log information to a central SysLog server.
episodes.title: Device Management Part 3

episodes.description: Having routers, firewalls and switches all over ones network opens the possibility to have each of the clocks to become unsynchronized. Having all the clocks synchronized on a system can help with doing things like tracking an attack vector and the best way to do that is through Network Time Protocol (NTP). Viewers will continue to hear about log messages and the importance of having synchronized clocks across all of your network equipment as well as see demonstrations on how to use the Network Time Protocol (NTP) to designate a centralized clock source and how to make an IOS device an NTP server.
episodes.title: Device Management Part 4

episodes.description: The Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) in IPv4 allows one to learn the network they are on, run a default gateway and learn the DNS and domain server to use. With IPv6, built into the protocol one can learn what network they are on and automatically have an address assigned to them. Viewers will hear about how to configure a Cisco IOS device as a DHCP server, the steps required to configure an IPv4 DHCP server and also about configuring DHCP for an IPv6 network.
episodes.title: DHCP

episodes.description: One will probably use Network Address Translation (NAT) for many different scenarios with IPv4, but not very many with IPv6, but should still know the concepts and differences between NPT and NAT64. Viewers will hear about the different forms of NAT, configuring NAT for IPv4 and how NAT64 and NPTv6 can be used to provide address translation under IPv6.
episodes.title: Network Address Translation

episodes.description: A Service Level Agreement (SLA) is essentially an agreement or guarantee that a level of service is being met. Viewers will hear about what SLAs are, how one can set them up for monitoring and some of the weaknesses in Cisco's self-healing network design as well as see demonstrations on how one can use IP SLAs and Tracking Objects to overcome those limitations and ensure one’s network re-routes properly during a network outage and how to use IP SLAs to report on network performance.
episodes.title: IP SLAs
